Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support for the 19th Quantum Information Processing Workshop (QIP 2016)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: The funds are requested to support student travel to Quantum Information Processing Workshop to be held at the Banff Centre in Canada, on 10-16 January, 2016. This workshop is the central event in the area of Quantum Computing and, more generally, Quantum Information Science. It is expected that QIP will bring together about 500 leading researchers in theoretical aspects of quantum information and computation, and play a role as one of the most important venues for the groundbreaking research in theoretical computer science. NSF support will help broaden participation at the QIP Workshop by subsidizing the travel for up to 20 student participants who might not otherwise attend QIP. Organizers aim at increasing the number of student and postdoctoral participants from the under-represented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
QIP (for Quantum Information Processing) is an annual conference on quantum computation and information, usually held in January. Its goal is to represent the preceding year's best research in the area, in the form of both invited and contributed talks.

In 2016 the conference took place at the research center of Banff in Canada. The goal of this travel grant was to allow U.S. graduate students to attend the conference by partially supporting their travel and housing costs. Participation by students and young emembers of the comunity in a major conference such as QIP is extremely important in developing their career, as it enables them to present their own research, learn about new developments in the field, and interact with more senior researchers. 

The travel grant consisted of $10,000. This amount was distributed among 14 successful applicants selected among a pool of 45 applicants in total, according to the criteria outlined in the proposal (in summary, scientific merit, representation of minorities, geographic representation). Among the 14 awards, one was made to an undergraduate student, 11 to graduate students, and 2 to postdoctoral scholars. 7 of the awards were made to female applicants. The awards were made to applicants coming from 8 different US institutions. All awardees presented original research, either in the form of a contributed talk or a poster at the conference.
